an6.45:4.1: “Mendicants, isn’t poverty suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”
an6.45:5.1: “When a poor, penniless person falls into debt, isn’t being in debt also suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?
an6.45:6.1: “When a poor person who has fallen into debt agrees to pay interest, isn’t the interest also suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”
an6.45:7.1: “When a poor person who has fallen into debt and agreed to pay interest fails to pay it when it falls due, they get a warning.
an6.45:7.2: Isn’t being warned suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”
an6.45:8.1: “When a poor person fails to pay after getting a warning, they’re prosecuted.
an6.45:8.2: Isn’t being prosecuted suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”
an6.45:9.1: “When a poor person fails to pay after being prosecuted, they’re imprisoned.
an6.45:9.2: Isn’t being imprisoned suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”
an6.45:10.1: “So mendicants, poverty, debt, interest, warnings, prosecution, and imprisonment are suffering in the world for those who enjoy sensual pleasures.
an6.45:10.2: In the same way, whoever has no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom when it comes to wholesome qualities
an6.45:10.3: is called poor and penniless in the training of the noble one.
an6.45:11.1: Since they have no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, or wisdom when it comes to wholesome qualities, they do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an6.45:11.2: This is how they’re in debt, I say.
an6.45:12.1: In order to conceal the bad things they do by way of body, speech, and mind they harbour corrupt wishes.
an6.45:12.2: They wish, plan, speak, and act with the thought: “Don’t let anyone find out about me.”
an6.45:12.6: This is how they pay interest, I say.
an6.45:13.1: Good-hearted spiritual companions say this about them:
an6.45:13.2: ‘This venerable acts like this, and behaves like that.’
an6.45:13.3: This is how they’re warned, I say.
an6.45:14.1: When they go to a wilderness, the root of a tree, or an empty hut, they’re beset by remorseful, unwholesome thoughts.
an6.45:14.2: This is how they’re prosecuted, I say.
an6.45:15.1: That poor, penniless person has done bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re trapped in the prison of hell or the animal realm.
an6.45:15.2: I don’t see a single prison that’s as brutal, as vicious, and such an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary as the prison of hell or the animal realm.”
an6.45:16.1: “Poverty is said to be suffering in the world,
an6.45:16.2: and so is being in debt.
an6.45:16.3: A poor person who has fallen in debt
an6.45:16.4: worries even when spending the loan.
an6.45:17.4: for someone who longs for pleasure and possessions.
an6.45:18.1: In the same way, in the noble one’s training
an6.45:19.4: They wish ‘May no-one find me out!’
an6.45:20.4: every which way, again and again.
an6.45:21.3: is a poor person who has fallen in debt,
an6.45:21.4: and worries even when spending the loan.
an6.45:22.1: And when in village or wilderness
an6.45:23.3: goes to one of the animal realms,
an6.45:24.2: from which a wise person is released.
an6.45:24.4: with wealth that is properly earned.
an6.45:25.3: welfare and benefit in this life,
an6.45:25.5: This is how, for a householder,
an6.45:26.1: In the same way, in the noble one’s training,
an6.45:26.4: wise, and restrained in ethical conduct,
an6.45:28.1: They give up the five hindrances,
an6.45:29.3: by not grasping in any way,
an6.45:30.1: To that poised one, rightly freed
an6.45:30.2: with the end of the fetters of rebirth,
an6.45:31.4: this is the highest freedom from debt.”
